title: I mixed acetone and bleach and left it outside for a few days and brought it inside. I smelt it and thought it might have resembled hay. Since phosgene is so toxic, should I go to the hospital? - Quora

response.answer_text: The reaction of acetone (CH3)2CO) with bleach (basic sodium hypochlorite, NaOCl) is shown below. (CH3)2CO + 6 NaOCl → CH3CO2-Na+ + CHCl3 + 2 NaOH + 3 NaCl This is, more or less, a variation of the iodoform reaction which results in the formation of chloroform (CHCl3) as well as sodium acetate (CH3CO2-Na+ ). Chloroform, in the presence of light and oxygen (…left outside for a few days) leads to the formation of phosgene (Cl2CO): CHCl3 + O2 → Cl3C-OOH Cl3C-OOH + H2O → Cl3C-OH + HOOHCl3C-OH → Cl2CO + HCl Phosgene, at low concentration, does smell like freshly mown hay. You should seek medical attention if you are experiencing the following signs - coughing, burning sensation in the throat and eyes, watery eyes, blurred vision, difficulty breathing, and/or nausea and vomiting, Of course, having these symptoms does not mean you were exposed to phosgene but given the circumstances, would be consistent with phosgene exposure. Most people who recover after exposure to phosgene make a complete recovery. However, chronic bronchitis and emphysema have been reported as a result of phosgene exposure.
